occurrences.line_text: And great Dame Natures handmaide, chearing euery kind.
Her chearing vp, thus gently to her sayd;
Himselfe to chearish, and consuming thought
It strength to me supplies, & chears my dulled spright.
But by the checked waue they did descry
Vpon checklaton he was straungely dight,
But being checkt, he did abstaine streight way,
Priuily moystening his horrid cheek.
Vpon her snowy cheeke; and therewithall
His cheeke bones raw, and eie-pits hollow grew,
Approching nigh vnto him cheeke by cheeke,
Approching nigh vnto him cheeke by cheeke,
Decking her cheeke with a vermilion rose:
His bare thin cheekes for want of better bits,
His raw-bone cheekes through penurie and pine,
With rosie cheekes, for shame as blushing red;
Did paint his chearefull cheekes, yet being ded,
And in her cheekes the vermeill red did shew
That cheekes with teares, and sides with bloud did all abound.
The bashfull bloud her snowy cheekes did dye,
With hollow eyes and rawbone cheekes forspent,
That in her cheekes made roses oft appeare:
And all her bones might through her cheekes be red;
Benumbes her cheekes: Then out aloud she cries,
But of his cheere did seeme too solemne sad;
His chaunge of cheere, that anguish did bewray,
To milk their gotes, and make them cheese and bred,
To keepe their flockes for litle hyre and chepe:
Downe hanging his dull head, with heauy chere,
Thence to depart with glee and gladsome chere.
Of that great Ladie, who with goodly chere
She gan reioyce, and shew triumphant chere,
Wherein the cherefull birds of sundry kind
And her against sweet Cherefulnesse was placed,
Therefore to cherish him with diets daint,
Her selfe to cherish, and her guest to cheare:
To cherish her with all things choice and rare;
Where all that night them selues they cherished,
Still when as he enfeebled was, him cherisht,
Sweete Goddesses all three which me in mirth do cherry.
Eftsoones he perced through his chaufed chest
When courage first does creepe in manly chest,
These words she breathed forth from riuen chest;
When the hart bloud should gush out of his chest,
Sorrow is heaped in thy hollow chest,
Vnwares it strooke into her snowie chest,
And catching hold of this Sea-beaten chest,
Chaunst to espy vpon her yuory chest
Did call diuine, that doth by Chester tend;
But huge great yron chests and coffers strong,
The fire of loue and ioy of cheualree
Greatly aduauncing his gay cheualree.
By dew desert of noble cheualree,
He had not trayned bene in cheualree.
But most they meruail[e]d at her cheualree,
Faire braunch of noblesse, flowre of cheualrie,
To whom no share in armes and cheualrie
Ne more renowmed for their cheualrie,
That with the praise of armes and cheualrie,
To deedes of armes and proofe of cheualrie
Then what prescribed were by lawes of cheualrie.
(Though none more noble then is cheualrie,)
In braue poursuit of cheualrous emprize,
Their minds to praise, and cheualrous desire:
Her louers shape, and cheualrous aray;
Ne better doth beseeme braue cheualry,
Whether ye list him traine in cheualry,
That was the flowre of grace and cheualrye;
The scorne of knighthood and trew cheualrye,
Fortune, the foe of famous cheuisaunce
Which reft from him so faire a cheuisaunce:
It were t'abandon noble cheuisaunce,
For Chian folke to pourtraict beauties Queene,
As chicken newly hatcht, from dreaded destiny.
And bid his faithlesse chickens ouerronne
His angry steede did chide his foming bitt,
Helpe then, O holy Virgin chiefe of nine,
The lesser pangs can beare, who hath endur'd the chiefe.
In chiefe degree are heaped vp on hye:
And Locrine left chiefe Lord of Britany.
For till his dayes, the chiefe dominion
Which was their chiefe and th'author of that strife:
Nor herbes, nor charmes, nor counsell, that is chiefe
In his chiefe Church, for endlesse moniments
Should of her name and nation be chiefe,
Whose chiefe desire is loue and friendly aid
Thereto he offred for to make him chiefe
Seeing his honor, which she tendred chiefe,
In euils counsell is the comfort chiefe,
But those three in the midst, doe chiefe on her attend.
And had the chiefe commaund of all the rest,
He from you take that chiefedome, which ye doe abuse.
But chiefely of the fairest Florimell,
Chiefely by him, whose life her law doth bynd,
The first and chiefest of the seuen, whose care
Albe Charissa were their chiefest founderesse.
But three the chiefest, and of greatest powre,
His chiefest lets and authors of his harmes,
Which alwayes of his paines he made the chiefest meed.
As from my chiefest foe me to release,
Therewith some other of the chiefest theeues
Of such (said he) I chiefly do inquere,
But chiefly skill to ride, seemes a science
But chiefly Paridell his hart did grate,
In which her kingdomes throne is chiefly resiant.
But chiefly by that yron page he ghest,
But chiefly Talus with his yron flayle,
But chiefly Calidore, whom griefe had most possest.
That forst their Chieftaine, for his safeties sake,
(Their Chieftaine Humber named was aright)
And is with child of glorious great intent,
O welcome child, whom I haue longd to see,
As carefull Nourse her child from falling oft does reare.
Me then he left enwombed of this child,
This lucklesse child, whom thus ye see with bloud defild.
Till him the child bespoke, Long lackt, alas,
Of my deare foster child, to ease thy griefe,
I fonder, then Cephisus foolish child,
The royall child with readie quicke foresight,
But the bold child that perill well espying,
Which when he saw, his hart was inly child
And in dew time a mayden child forth brought.
By this Charissa, late in child-bed brought,
Exceeding shone, like Phoebus fairest childe,
For ransome leauing him the late borne childe;
He hearkned to his reason, and the childe
Be to thy foster Childe, that from thy hand
Vpon a day she found this gentle childe,
Like as a wayward childe, whose sounder sleepe
Vppon the childe, but somewhat short did fall,
Nought fear'd the childe his lookes, ne yet his threats,
Most pensiue man, through feare, what of his childe became.
The noble childe preuenting his desire,
With which she from her childhood had bene fed.
And lull in rugged armes, withouten childish feare.
Their wanton sports and childish mirth did play,
And shewst th'ensa[m]ple of thy childish might,
Amongst his peres playing his childish sport:
Or who shall not great Nightes children scorne,
And can the children of faire light deface.
The fall of famous children borne of mee,
Her children deare, whom he away had wonne:
And them before, the fry of children young
The children of one sire by mothers three;
Apes, Lions, ï¿½/-gles, Owles, fooles, louers, children, Dames.
So many children he did multiply;
Till that her sisters children, woxen strong
Dayes dearest children be the blessed seed,
Vngratious children of one gracelesse sire,
Foolhardy as th'Earthes children, the which made
Her name was Agape whose children werne
The which in seeking for her children three
Her land, and slaine her children ruefully alas.
Giuing her dearest children one by one
Ere all her children he from her had reft.
For all her other children, through affray,
My children and my people, burnt in flame;
Be lacke of children, to supply your place,
And eke thy childrens thrids to be asunder burst.
That she might see her childre[n]s thrids forth brought,
Latonaes childrens wrath, that all her issue wasted.
And chearefull bloud in faintnesse chill did melt,
Of his ill newes, did inly chill and quake,
He shooke off luskishnesse, and courage chill
And one great chimney, whose long tonnell thence,
And fell Chimï¿½ra in her darkesome den,
There thirstie Tantalus hong by the chin;
To rub her temples, and to chaufe her chin,
Deepe was he drenched to the vpmost chin,
That to the chin he cleft his head in twaine:
And cleft his head asunder to his chin.
Whom Calidore thus carried on his chine,
Chirpe loud to thee out of their leauy cages,
That bore great sway in armes and chiualrie,
And Dart, nigh chockt with sands of tinny mines.
In choice, and change of thy deare loued Dame,
A place pickt out by choice of best aliue,
Yet at her choice they all did greatly muse.
To cherish her with all things choice and rare;
Thus farre forth pardon, sith that choicest wit
Perdie (said Britomart) the choise is hard:
Fro loue to hate, a change of euill choise:
Vnto my choise by no meanes would assent,
That of their loues choise they might freedom clame,
Bene choisely picked out from all the rest,
And choisest med'cine for sicke harts reliefe:
Redounding teares did choke th'end of her plaint,
Faire Sthenoboea, that her selfe did choke
With thundring noyse, and all the ayre doth choke,
That all the land with stench, and heauen with horror choke.
Both horse and man nigh able for to choke;
And dreadfull horrour did all entraunce choke,
Did choke the entraunce with a lumpe of sin,
That welnigh choked with the deadly stinke,
That him nigh choked with the deadly stinke:
And gaspe for breath, that he nigh choked was,
Choking the remnant of his plaintife speach,
Which chokt the porch of that enchaunted gate,
But strained him so streightly, that he chokt him neare.
Trembling through hasty rage, whe[n] choler in him sweld.
Whose grieued mindes, which choler did englut,
Chaufing and foming choler each against his fo.
As fayning choler, which was turn'd to cold:
But rather in them kindled choler new.
But Guyon did his choler pacify,
And softly royne, when saluage choler gan redound.
That he streight way with haughtie choler burned,
And bad him choose, what death he would desire:
Do rather choose my flitting houres to spend,
Who with his wisedom won, him streight did choose
Gan choose his dame with Basciomani gay,
That now he chooseth, with vile difference,
Then choosing out few wordes most horrible,
Which choosing for that euenings hospitale,
So choosing solitarie to abide,
Chopt off, and nayld on high, that all might the[m] behold.
As he to peeces would haue chopt it quight:
And many Bardes, that to the trembling chord
During which time, the Chorle through her so kind
He seeing with that Chorle so faire a wight,
The fearefull Chorle durst not gainesay, nor doe,
Of those he chose out two, the falsest twoo,
And chose in Faery court of meere goodwill,
Vpon a slouthfull Asse he chose to ryde,
That euer Ladie to her loue did chose,
Both hungred after death: both chose to win, or die.
He chose, which he had kept long time in darksome den.
He chose an halter from among the rest,
That chose the narrow path, or seeke the right:
He now this Ladies champion chose for loue to fight.
More rype vs reason lent to chose our Peares,
Disleall knight, whose coward courage chose
Themselues to court, and each a Damsell chose:
Their fit disports with faire delight doe chose,
But rather chose to dye for sorrow great,
The second was an holy Nunne to chose,
But chose emongst the iolly Satyres still to wonne.
Whom Ioue did loue, and chose his cup to beare,
They by consent should chose the stoutest three,
Those warlike champions both together chose,
But boastfull Braggadocchio rather chose,
For wofull wight, chose out a gloomy glade,
Which he had lately seene, that for his loue he chose.
Chose Artegall to right her to restore;
And rather chose his challenge off to breake,
And rather guilty chose him selfe to yield.
He chose with shame to beare that Ladies head
I rather chose to die in liues despight,
Him entertayn'd, and did her champion chose:
Vnto your selfe I freely leaue to chose,
Some with their eyes the daintest morsels chose;
They for their Iudge did Pastorella chose;
And shrunken synewes of her chosen knight,
Why shouldst thou then despeire, that chosen art?
For those to dwell in, that are chosen his,
His chosen people purg'd from sinfull guilt,
It was a chosen plot of fertile land,
Was by the people chosen in their sted,
But hauing chosen, now he might not chaunge.
And choseth vertue for his dearest Dame,
O who is that, which brings me happy choyce
Sir Calepine by chaunce, more then by choyce,
Disperseth them to catch his choysest pray;
Thereby a Christall streame did gently play,
Like sunny beames threw from her Christall face,
And that bright towre all built of christall cleene,
Some wrestle, some do run, some bathe in christall flood.
Who all of Christall did Panthea build:
The trembling groues, the Christall running by;
Which drops of Christall seemd for wantones to weepe.
So through the Christall waues appeared plaine:
Whose face did seeme as cleare as Christall stone,
The Christall humour stood congealed rownd;
But soone as calmed was the Christall aire,
With that adowne out of her Christall eyne
Pure in aspect, and like to christall glasse,
On which the waues, glittering like Christall glas,
Laomedia, like the christall sheene;
Vpon the litle brest like christall bright,
Christalline humour dropped downe apace.
The sacred pledge of Christes Euangely;
That first receiued Christianitie,
On which true Christians bloud was often spilt,
A chronicle of Briton kings,
And many Chroniclers, that can record
Mightie Chrysaor, and Caicus strong;
Gainst highest heauen; Chrysaor it was hight;
Chrysaor that all other swords excelled,
With bright Chrysaor in his cruell hand,
He stroke him with Chrysaor on the hed,
By what straunge accident faire Chrysogone
So sprong these twinnes in wombe of Chrysogone,
Her mother was the faire Chrysogonee,
The younger daughter of Chrysogonee,
Vnto the Church, their prayers to appeale,
And holy Church with faithlesse hands deface,
In his chiefe Church, for endlesse moniments
Which battring, downe it on the church doth glance,
For sacrilege me seem'd the Church to rob,
Britomart comes to Isis Church,
Then wote you, Sir, that in this Church hereby,
So to the Church he came, where it was told,
From thence into the sacred Church he broke,
Wont to robbe Churches of their ornaments,
The Churches part, and Ploughmans portion,
Of a rude churle, whom often he accused
The Churne, and Charwell, two small streames, which   pained
Which who hath skill them rightly to haue chusd,
And fed with words, that could not chuse but please,
Refuse such fruitlesse toile, and present pleasures chuse.
Mammon was much displeasd, yet no'te he chuse,
But either Gloriana let her chuse,
And him doth chyde as false and fraudulent,
And chyde at him, that made her misbelieue:
One mother, when as her foolehardie chyld
She with him liues, and hath him borne a chyld,
In her owne mouth the food, ment for her chyld,
But then aread, thou gentle chyld, wherefore
Threatning to chastize me, as doth t'a chyld pertaine.
And thus replide; Faire chyld, the high desire
Chyld Tristram prayd, that he with him might goe
That from his sides some noble chyld should rize,
As his owne chyld; for other he had none,
Yet chylde ne kinsman liuing had he none
Him selfe, whose minde did trauell as with chylde,
To saue her chylde, which in misfortunes mouth was plaste.
Who euer is the mother of one chylde,
A little mayde, the which ye chylded tho;
That quite it chynd his backe behind the sell,
Mortall Samnitis, and Cicuta bad,
With blistred hands emongst the cinders brent,
Out of the burning cinders, and therewith
Nine was the circle set in heauens place,
Whose circled waters rapt with whirling sway,
Which in great heapes them circled all about,
Whose sides with dapled circles weren dight;
Her faire lockes in rich circlet be enrold,
The frame thereof seemd partly circulare,
So did Decetto eke him circumuent,
So farre from court and royall Citadell,
Which to a goodly Citie led his vew;
The Citie of the great king hight it well,
And with great ioy into that Citie wend,
Now are they Saints all in that Citie sam,
The fairest Citie was, that might be seene;
For this great Citie that does far surpas,
Of Troian warres, and Priams Citie sackt,
The Troian Brute did first that Citie found,
They came vnto a Citie farre vp land,
And that same citie, so now ruinate,
Castles surprizd, great cities sackt and brent:
For all thy Cities they shall sacke and race,
Towres, Cities, Kingdomes ye would ruinate,
He was not in the Cities wofull fyre
Cannot two fairer Cities find this day,
Great cities ransackt, and strong castles rast,
My cities sackt, and their sky-threating towres
By whose aduise old Priams cittie fell,
She then the Citties sought from gate to gate,
And gathering them vnto her citties gate,
Out of the pleasant soyle, and citties glad,
Which there stood gazing from the Citties wall
Him first from court he to the citties coursed,
And from the citties to the townes him prest,
A goodly citty and a mighty one,
Descried streight; who all the citty warned,
So forth she came out of the citty gate,
Of that faire City, wherein make abode
By many a city, and by many a towne,
Before the city gate, in open sight;
And magistrates of all that city made,
And ciuile armes to exercise no more:
Which had them traynd in all ciuilitee,
And spreds it selfe through all ciuilitie:
But they that breake bands of ciuilitie,
To firends, to foes, which skill men call Ciuility.
And shortly brought to ciuill gouernaunce,
Who making vantage of their ciuill iarre,
And ciuill rule to kings and states imperiall.
Till vniuersall peace compound all ciuill iarre.
All ciuill vsage and gentility,
Was the disturber of all ciuill life,
Of vertue and of ciuill vses lore,
And mutining, to stirre vp ciuill faction,
And roote of ciuill conuersation.
Her all in white he clad, and ouer it
Then vp he rose, and clad him hastily;
A goodly Lady clad in scarlot red,
In greene vine leaues he was right fitly clad;
And in a foule blacke pitchie mantle clad,
Who earst in flowres of freshest youth was clad.
Right cleanly clad in comely sad attire;
Was clad in blew, that her beseemed well;
With which bare wretched wights he dayly clad,
A comely Palmer, clad in blacke attire,
But when as him all in bright armour clad
A goodly Ladie clad in hunters weed,
And richly clad in robes of royaltye,
Vprose Sir Guyon, in bright armour clad,
Clad in faire weedes, but fowle disordered,
So was that chamber clad in goodly wize,
Royally clad (quoth he) in cloth of gold,
And then of him are clad with other hew,
Griefe all in sable sorrowfully clad,
Clad in a vesture of vnknowen geare,
Both clad in colours like, and like array,
So being clad, she brought him from the field,
All clad in linnen robes with siluer hemd;
In which when as she him anew had clad,
Him clad in th'armour of a Pagan knight,
A beuie of faire Virgins clad in white,
A Lions clawes, with powre and rigour clad,
Yet wondrous faire she was, and richly clad
All in a woodmans iacket he was clad
Clad all in gilden armes, with azure band
To clad his corpse with meete habiliments,
With a faire Mayden clad in mourning weed,
Which though it were a cottage clad with lome,
So being clad, vnto the fields he went
Like the faire Morning clad in misty fog did shew.
Both clad in shepheards weeds agreeably,
Y cladd in mightie armes and siluer shielde,
She claim'd that to her selfe, as Ladies det,
And both the liuing Lady claime your right,
By what right doe you claime to be your owne?
And said, Sir Knight, sith ye this Lady clame,
That of their loues choise they might freedom clame,
I cald, but no man answerd to my clame.
First the Sea-gods, which to themselues doe clame
And from the heritage, which she did clame,
His owne good steed, which he had stolne, to clame;
Him charge with guilt, but rather doe quite clame:
To all the heathen Gods, might like to this be clamed.
Them guyded through the throng, that did their clamors ceasse.
They ceast their clamors vpon them to gaze;
Of cryes and clamors, which amongst them past,
To weeten what that sudden clamour ment;
Did clap her hands, and ioyed at that dolefull sight.
These three so noble babes to bring forth at one clap.
That all the castle ringed with the clap.
Throughout the house, that clapped euery dore,
Shouting, and clapping all their hands on hight,
And clapt his yron wings, as victor he did dwell.
And clapt on hie his coulourd winges twaine,
And Clare, and Harwitch both doth beautify:
Ne should faire Claribell with all her art,
To weet, sterne Druon, and lewd Claribell,
The more was Claribell enraged rife
And Blandamour to Claribell relide.
Of Claribell and Blandamour attone;
Then good sir Claribell him thus bespake,
Her name was Claribell: whose father hight
Thus long continu'd Claribell a thrall,
Long since had fought in field. Als Claribell
With Claribell, whylest he that monster sought
With thanks to Bellamour and Claribell,
The daughter of her Lady Claribell,
In Claribellaes clothes. Her proper face
Her name was Clarin, and thus to her sayd;
Clarin (sayd she) thou seest yond Fayry Knight,
Ne euer did deceiptfull Clarin find
And to her said; Clarinda whom of all
Goe now, Clarinda, well thy wits aduise,
Certes Clarinda, not of cancred will,
What now is left Clarinda? what remaines,
Euen so Clarinda her owne Dame beguyld,
But wrought by Clarins wile.
With shaumes, & trompets, & with Clarions sweet;
The whiles shril trompets & loud clarions sweetly playd.
Some Clarkes doe doubt in their deuicefull art,
And clash their shields, and shake their swords on hy,
For as the clashing of an Armour bright,
Or clashing heard, he fast away did fly,
Their clasping armes, in wanton wreathings intricate.
And clasping twixt his armes, her vp did reare
Good Claudius, that next was Emperour,
For one of them was like an Eagles claw,
To plucke a bone, then from his cruell claw
For as a Bittur in the Eagles claw,
With his rude clawes the wicket open rent,
And seizing cruell clawes on trembling brest,
Haue reft away with his sharpe rending clawes:
From Lyons clawes to pluck the griped pray.
Who on his necke his bloudie clawes did seize,
The sharpnesse of his cruell rending clawes;
Till with his cruell clawes he snatcht the wood,
In smithes fire-spitting forge, and nayles like clawes appeard.
He ouer him did hold his cruell clawes,
And some had wings, and some had clawes to teare,
Whose clawes were newly dipt in cruddy blood,
Whence he with crooked clawes so long did crall,
As when a Beare hath seiz'd her cruell clawes
But first the Tygre clawes thereon did lay;
A Lions clawes, with powre and rigour clad,
Her Lions clawes he from her feete away did wipe.
Like puttocks clawes: with th'one of which she scracht
And threatning his sharpe clawes, now wanting powre to straine.
That with fell clawes full of fierce gourmandize,
As if he would haue rent him with his cruell clawes.
And with fresh clay did close the wooden wound:
